Source Notes: Borrowed from Albanian škrumb {shkrumb} [Orel 1998: 423-424].
Borrowed from Italian {cenere} 'ashes'.
Borrowed from Albanian škrumb {shkrumb} [Orel 1998: 423–424].
Polysemy: 'bark / peel'. Of Arabic origin [DCVB 2015].

Borrowed from Spanish {corteza} 'bark'. There is also a word koɾt-ˈiθ-a {cortiza} mentioned by Fernández Armesto as 'bark' [Fernández Armesto 1981: 224], but according to [Montoya Bolaños 2016] it rather means 'cork'. Distinct from kˈask-a {casca} (native term) or kˈask-ar-a {cáscara} (borrowed from Spanish) 'peel of a fruit / egg's shell' [Montoya Bolaños 2016].
Borrowed from Croatian {kora} 'bark'. Byhan also mentions the word kˈož-ä {kóẑę} 'bark' of Slavic origin [Byhan 1899: 250], but it is absent from Kovačec's dictionary in this meaning.

Borrowed from Croatian {trbuh} 'belly'. Byhan also mentions the words medˈul {medúl} belly' [Byhan 1899: 273] and rˈɒns-ä {rǫ´nsę} 'swollen belly' [Byhan 1899: 330-331], which are absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.  _x0015_Distinct from štˈumig {ștúmig} 'stomach' (and a contaminated form štulbix {ștulbih}) [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 285-286], yedɲak {iedńac} 'stomach' and želudac {jeludaţ} 'stomach' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 218], budˈil-ä {budílę} or mɒc {måţ} 'guts' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 226], drob {drob} 'intestines' [Kovačec 2010], Borrowed from Croatian {trbuh} 'belly'.  _x0015_Žejane: fˈol-e {fóle} 'belly' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 213; Byhan 1899: 216-217].
Borrowed from Italian {ventre} 'belly', replacing pˈanc-a {panza}, which now has an archaic or a more colloquial shade of meaning [Selva 2015].

1985: 356; Gancz 2015. There are two expressions for 'belly': bˈurt-ə {burtă} and pˈɨnteč-e {pântece}, the latter with polysemy: 'belly, stomach / womb'. According to [Gancz 2015], they are synonyms, but the first one is more frequent. Has no certain etymology. Distinct from abdomˈen {abdomen} of French origin, used as a scientific term [Gancz 2015], vˈintr-e {vintre} 'belly', which is used in some dialects [DEaLR 2015] and stomˈak {stomac} 'stomach' of Greek origin [DEaLR 2015]. Moldavian: bˈurt-ə {burtă} 'belly' [Podiko 1973: 209; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 112].
Rifondou: aɲ-iː {hagnî} 'to bite'.

The second one means 'ugly / bad / black', according to Bartoli, and can be found in the meaning 'black' only once: {l-avás el kolár… spatáte uṅ pák… nán-e ri…} "it has a colour… wait a moment… it is not black…" [Bartoli 2002: 240]. The third word is mentioned only by Cubich in his vocabulary [Bartoli 2002: 269] and in two contexts: {Jaime de vain vetrún, juálb, fosc, ruass, dole, garb} "We have wine old, white, black, red, sweet, gentle} [Bartoli 2002: 288-289]; {el jéra spuárc e fosc} "he was dirty and black" [Bartoli 2002: 288]. The first word is written down by Ive from Udina and it means 'black' without any doubts ({fúrme un páuk de pun juálb e un páuk de niár} "we will make some white bread and some brown (literally 'black')" [Bartoli 2002: 297-298]; {túnte tiáste de píre blánke e niáre} "a multitude of white and black sheep" [Bartoli 2002: 299-300]), so we choose it for the list. The form nyar {niár} is a "dalmatianized" borrowing from Venetian.
Distinct from pˈɛtr-o {pètro} 'gizzard'.

Along with this term, Viret also mentions fwaːʎ-ˈiː {fwâlyî} and kraːm-ˈaː {krâmâ}, without differentiating them. In another entry he translates fwaːʎ-ˈiː {fwâlyî} as 'to blaze (intransitive)', so we include only brüːl-ˈaː {brûlâ} and kraːm-ˈaː {krâmâ} in the list.

Borrowed from Croatian {paliti} 'to burn'. Distinct from ˈɒrde {årde} 'to burn' (intr.) [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 188; Byhan 1899: 297] and usturˈɒ {usturå} 'to sting' (intr.) [Byhan 1899: 377].
There are two expressions for 'to burn': brül-ˈa {brula} and kɾem-ˈa {crema}. Coupier mentions them as synonyms.

There is no word for 'cloud' either in Kovačec's dictionary or in the texts. Borrowed from Croatian {oblak} 'cloud'. Distinct from mˈəɣl-a {mấɣla} (Žejane) 'fog' of Croatian origin [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 282].

Probably borrowed from Italian {bracco} 'hound' of Germanic origin. Byhan also mentions the word kˈuc-ä {kútsę} of Croatian origin, which is used in baby talk [Byhan 1899: 260]. Žejane (also occurs in Nova Vas): kˈər-e {cấre} 'dog' [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 197; Byhan 1899: 253].
Borrowed from French {chien} 'dog'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} ˈto eatˈ.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} ˈto eatˈ.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} ˈto eatˈ.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} ˈto eatˈ.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} ˈto eatˈ.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} ˈto eatˈ.

Phonetic variants: bdy-iː {bdyî} ~ bǯy-iː {bdjyî} ~ mdy-iː {mdyî} ~ mǯy-iː {mdjyî} ~ mǯ-iː {mdjî}. Distinct from kas-ˈaː {kassâ} 'to eat', which belongs to informal speech. Annecy: mdy-iː {mdyî} 'to eat', pek-ˈaː {pekâ} 'to eat'; Saint-Pierre-de-Genebroz, Saint-Pierre-de-Soucy: pek-ˈaː {pekâ} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'. The term may-ˈa {maià} 'to eat' is less frequent and more colloquial [Selva 2015].
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.

some examples: {Di bere e di mangiar n'accende cura} "Desire to eat and drink enkindles in us" [Purg. 23]; {ché Branca Doria non morì unquanche, // e mangia e bee e dorme e veste panni} "for Branca d' Oria is not dead as yet, // and eats, and drinks, and sleeps, and puts on clothes" [Inf. 34]. The form manduk-ˈa-re {manducare} 'to eat' is attested twice, both times in the end of a line: {e come 'l pan per fame si manduca} "and even as bread through hunger is devoured" [Inf. 32]; {che ogni senso // co li denti d'Amor già mi manduca} "which already // is devouring all my senses with the teeth // of Love" [Rime 103].
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'. Distinct from məʎ-ˈar {magliar} 'eat (of animal)' [Pallioppi & Pallioppi 1895: 435].
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.
Giarre: manǯ-ˈa-ɾi {mangiari} 'to eat' [Sorbello 2015]. Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'.

Ornato 2015; La Bua 2015. Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'. Distinct from pisti-ˈa-ɾi {pistiari} of Greek origin, which is more vulgar [Ornato 2015]. Buscemi: manč-ˈa-ɾi {manciari} 'to eat' [Coccimiglio 2016].
Borrowed from Old French {mangier} 'to eat'. Distinct from the obsolete term manːuk-ˈa-ɾi {mannucari} 'to eat' [Leggio 2015].
Polysemy: 'lard / fat'. Borrowed from Croatian {mast} 'fat'. Distinct from zˈɒbil-ä {zåbilę} 'roux' [Kovačec 2010].
Borrowed from Latin {pluma} 'feather'. Langreo: plˈum-a {pluma} 'feather / down' [González Rato 2016].
Polysemy: 'feather / down'. Borrowed from Latin {pluma} 'feather'.
Borrowed from Italian {piuma}. Distinct from pˈinː-a {pinna} 'pen, pencil, membrum virile' [Miccichè 2015].
Borrowed from Latin {pluma} 'feather'. Distinct from plum-ˈon {plumón} 'down' [Valén 2015].

Some examples are: {ju manako vuai ku͡ọrno per prínz, pas} "Today I am having meat for lunch, fish" [Bartoli 2002: 242]; {pas frit} 'fried fish' [Bartoli 2002: 243].The form pyas {pas} is a "dalmatianized" borrowing from Venetian. The inherited form is attested by Cubich as {pasch} [Bartoli 2002: 280] and by Petris as {pask} [Bartoli 2002: 295].
Borrowed from Croatian {riba} 'fish'. Byhan also mentions the word pešt {peŝt} [Byhan 1899: 305], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
Borrowed from French {viande} 'meat'. Distinct from kaɾ {car} 'meat', which is less frequent [Coupier 1995: 1476].
Borrowed from Croatian {letjeti} 'to fly'.
-əy- is an imperfective suffix. Probably borrowed from Slavic (cf. Old Church Slavonic {pariti} 'soar, hover').
Borrowed from Catalan {donar} 'to give' [Narumov 2001: 184]. Domus de Maria: dˈɔn-ay {donai} 'to give' [Fadda 2015].

Some examples are: {pletást la butúa la kolár várd} "rather tends to be of green colour" [Bartoli 2002: 240]; {col cóplo viard in tiásta} "with a green hat on her head" [Bartoli 2002: 299-300]. The form vyard {várd} is a "dalmatianized" borrowing from Venetian.

Borrowed from Croatian. The inherited term for 'green' vˈärd-e {vę́rde} is preserved in the meaning 'unripe' and in the term for an evergreen tree {vę́rdele spir} [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 297; Byhan 1899: 380]. Cf. {vęrdu nåp} 'raw turnip'.
Distinct from pɛɫ {pèl} ˈbody hairˈ [Pérez i Sanchis]. Borrowed from the Standard Catalan [Pedrós 2015].
Borrowed from French {cheveu} 'hair'. Distinct from pay {pai} 'body hair' [Viret 2013: 1667-1668].
Probably influenced by Standard Italian {mano} 'hand'. Distinct from vrˈačː-u {vracciu} 'arm' [Monti Barnocchi-Moscati 2016].

Borrowed from Old French {entendre} 'to hear'. There are two expressions for 'to hear': en=tˈɛnd-ɾe {entèndre} and awz-ˈi {ausi}. Coupier mentions them as synonyms. Distinct from eskut-ˈa {escouta} 'to listen' [Coupier 1995: 457].
There are two expressions for 'heavy': luɾd {lourd}, which is evidently borrowed from French, and pˈɛwǯ-e {péuge} ~ pˈez-ant {pesant}. Coupier mentions them as synonyms.
Of Gaulish origin.
Of Gaulish origin. The inherited term kɔɾn {corn} is preserved in the meaning 'horn (instrument)' [Alòs i Font 2015].
Of Gaulish origin.
Of Gaulish origin.
Of Gaulish origin.
Of Gaulish origin.
Of Gaulish origin. Distinct from kˈɔɾn-o {corno} 'horn as substance' [Coupier 1995: 305].
1989: 544-545. Borrowed from old Spanish {chifle} 'horn', derived from {chiflar} 'to whistle' [Nascentes 1955: 114].
Distinct from the obsolete term mat-ˈa {mata} 'to kill' [Coupier 1995: 1447].
Distinct from the obsolete term mat-ˈa {mata} 'to kill' [Coupier 1995: 1447].
1985: 1530; Gancz 2015. Borrowed from some Slavic source [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: a=omor-ˈɨ {a omorî} 'to kill' [Podiko 1973: 966; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 457].
Borrowed from Macedonian {crn drob} 'liver' or Bulgarian {čeren drob} 'liver'.

Borrowed from Croatian {muški} 'male, masculine' (adjective). Cf. the informal nominalized adjective {mužský} 'man' in Czech. Another Croatism, muškarac  {mușcaraţ} 'man' is mentioned by Sârbu and Frăţilă [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 231]. Byhan also mentions the word bərbˈɒt {borbǫ́t} 'man' [Byhan 1899: 198], which is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.

Borrowed from Croatian Chakavian {čuda} 'much, a lot, many'. In the comparative form may=mˈunt {ma múnt} the old term is preserved [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 231; Byhan 1899: 284; Glavina 1905: 74]. There are also Croatisms nˈoɣo {nóɣo} 'many' and veȶ {vet″} / vˈiše {víșe} 'more', which are sometimes used as well [Kovačec 2010; Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 298].

Does not have a separate entry in the EDCT, but very frequently occurs in texts, cf. some examples: {.I. cercle d'or ovré a flors // de maintes diverses colors // les puceles el chief li metent} "The maids, moreover, wove a fillet of flowers of many various colours and placed it upon her head" (Erec 1639-1641); {antor li avoit mainte dame} "round about her was many a fair lady" (Erec 2405); {Se li ciax chiet et terre font, // dons sera prise mainte aloe} "if the sky fails and the earth melts, then many a lark will be caught" (Erec 4408-4409); {li rois Evrains, cui niés je sui, // m'adoba veant mainz prodomes} "King Evrain, whose nephew I am, dubbed me a knight in the presence of many honourable men" (Erec 6020-6021). The inherited term mowt {mout} is usually used in the meaning 'very', but occasionally occurs as 'many', cf. {Lucans i fu li botelliers; // mout i ot de boens chevaliers} "Lucan the cupbearer was there, too, and many another doughty knight" (Erec 1509-1510).
A possible substrate borrowing. Distinct from mont {mont} 'heap / mountain' [DILF 2001: 496].

A possible substrate borrowing. There are two expressions for 'mountain' in Forni's dictionary: krəp {crëp} and mont {mont}. The second one is used mostly in the meaning 'mountain pasture', figuratively and in some collocations (cf. {jì sa mont a sië} "to go to the mountain pasture to scythe grass"; {na mont de libri} "a heap of books" (literally "a mountain"); {na utia da mont} "alpine refuge"; {l nëiv sun la montes} "it is snowing on the relief"; {jì da mont su} / {jì sa mont} / {jì su per chëla montes} "to go to mountains" [Forni 2015]), while the first one is more common.
A Venetian borrowing.
1989: 42. Borrowed from Latin {proximus}.
Used also in the prohibitive function, cf. {Va pa!} "Don't go!" [Fiandro 2015].
Used also in prohibitive function, cf. {Va pa!} "Don't go!" [Sanero 2015].

Borrowed from Italian {uomo} 'man / person'. Gartner also mentions the term krištˈyaŋ {krištáŋ} 'Christian / man' [Gartner 1923: 42, 161] (see the Romansh word for 'man / person'), but in Forni's dictionary it is used only in the first meaning [Forni 2015].
Distinct from karetˈeɾ-a {carretera} 'asphalted road'. Langreo: kamˈiŋ {camín} 'road', karetˈeɾ-a {carretera} 'asphalted road' [González Rato 2016].
Borrowed from Gaulish.

Borrowed from Gaulish {cammano-} 'path, way' < Proto-Celtic {*kanxsman} 'step' via Vulgar Latin {*camminus} 'path, way' [Matasović 2009: 188-189]. Distinct from kərət-ˈeɾ-ə {carretera} 'asphalt road' [Llorens 2015].
Borrowed from Gaulish. Distinct from karet-ˈeɾ-a {carretera} 'asphalt road' [Pedrós 2015].
Borrowed from Gaulish.
Borrowed from Gaulish.
Borrowed from Gaulish.

In Bartoli's vocabulary the inherited term strˈwot-a {stru͡ọta} 'road' serves as the main equivalent [Bartoli 2002: 256], but in the texts Udina uses only the word kal {kal} 'road' (attested in Cubich's vocabulary [Bartoli 2002: 269]), of Venetian origin. Some examples are: {la sińara strasinúa per la kál el su vistát} "the lady drags her dress crossing the road" [Bartoli 2002: 244]; {toče le kale fero jelu͡ọte} "all the roads are frozen" [Bartoli 2002: 236]; {toče le kale fero pláne} "all the roads are full (of men)" [Bartoli 2002: 236]; {le kal fero strét} "the roads are narrow" [Bartoli 2002: 247].

Example: {Vai camiñando polo camiño} "He is walking on the road" [Montoya Bolaños 2016]. Distinct from estɾˈað-a {estrada} 'asphalted road' [Montoya Bolaños 2016]. Distinct from vˈi-a {vía} 'way, road' in a broad or specific meaning (for example, {vía do tren} "train track", {Vía Láctea} "Milky Way" or {vía de servicio} "service way") [Montoya Bolaños 2016].

Distinct from kˈal-i {cáli} 'way' [Capidan 1935: 56]. Cf. {feata află tru cali un zapti} "the girl met a guard on her way" [Capidan 1928: 109]; {džumiteata di cali} "a half of the way" [Capidan 1928: 111]; {mejlucu di cali} "a middle of the way" [Capidan 1928: 117].    _x0015_Borrowed from Greek {δρόμος} 'road'.
Of Gaulish origin. Distinct from ʁˈut-o {routo} 'highway, asphalt road' [Coupier 1995: 1251-1252].

1985: 325-326; Gancz 2015. Borrowed from Greek {δρόμος} 'road' [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from kˈal-e {cale} 'way' [Gancz 2015]. Moldavian: drum {drum} 'road'[Podiko 1973: 188; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 100].

Borrowed from Gaulish {cammano-} 'path, way' < Proto-Celtic {*kanxsman} 'step' via Vulgar Latin {*camminus} 'path, way' [Matasović 2009: 188-189]. Distinct from karet-ˈeɾ-a {carretera} 'highway, asphalt road' [Valén 2015].
Borrowed from some Slavic source.
Borrowed from Italian {radice} 'root'.
Borrowed from Macedonian {koren} 'root' or Bulgarian {koren} 'root'.
Apparently with polysemy: 'round 3D / round 2D'. Probably borrowed from Italian or Venetian {tondo} 'round'.
Probably borrowed from some Romance language, cf. Romansh {sablun} 'sand'. Sârbu and Frăţilă also mention the Croatism pesak {pesac} 'sand' [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 249].
Borrowed from Macedonian {pesok} 'sand'.
1985: 987; Gancz 2015. Borrowed from some Slavic source [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: nisˈip {nisip} 'sand' [Podiko 1973: 594; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 293].
The example is {el bragóṅ kart} "short pants" [Bartoli 2002: 232]. A Venetian borrowing.
Borrowed from Macedonian {kus} 'short'.
Polysemy: 'skin / hide'. Borrowed from some Slavic source.

Polysemy: 'skin / hide / nutshell'. Apart from ˈkoažə in Capidan's dictionary, there are also such words as ȶˈal-i {cháli} [Capidan 1935: 68] and mišˈin {mișín} [Capidan 1935: 192], but they cannot be found in texts.   _x0015_Borrowed from Slavic.
Borrowed from Old Greek {μικρός} 'small'.
Buscemi: nˈik-u {nicu} 'small' [Coccimiglio 2016]. Borrowed from Old Greek {μικρός} 'small'.
Borrowed from Old Greek {μικρός} 'small'.

Notes: Originally marked in source as not a borrowing.
Source Notes: Distinct from minˈut-ŭ {minút} 'tiny' [Papahagi 1963: 686; Cunia 2010: 656-657; Dalametra 1906: 132].

Notes: Originally marked in source as not a borrowing.
Source Notes: In Šušnjevica dialect, there is also a Croatism: mˈiȶi {míći} 'small' [Kovačec 2010].

Notes: Originally marked in source as not a borrowing.
Source Notes: In his dictionary Capidan also mentions miˈnut {minút} 'small' [Capidan 1935: 191], but mik is much more frequently used in texts; furthermore, it is mik that is opposed to the word 'big' in the riddle {Mic sam, mari sam, toată lumea u ạnves} "I am small, I am big, I clothed all the world" [Capidan 1928: 152].

Notes: Originally marked in source as not a borrowing.
Source Notes: 1985: 611; Gancz 2015. Goes back to the Vulgar Latin {*miccus}, which can be related with {mica} 'crumb', or be borrowed from Greek {μικρός} (Doric {μικκός}) 'small' or be of expressive origin [Ciorănescu 2015]. Moldavian: mik {mic} 'small' [Podiko 1973: 369; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 191].
The second part of this construction is borrowed from some Slavic source, while the first one means 'to sit'.
Borrowed from Spanish {estrella} 'star'.

There are two terms for 'star' in Central Catalan: əstɾˈeʎ-ə {estrella} and əstˈɛɫ {estel}. The second one is inherited, while the first one is borrowed from Spanish {estrella} 'star'. The first one is more frequent, but due to puristic tendencies, the second one is currently gaining in frequency [Alòs i Font 2015].
Borrowed from Spanish {estrella} 'star'.
Borrowed from Spanish {estrella} 'star'.
Borrowed from Spanish {estrella} 'star'.
Borrowed from Spanish {estrella} 'star'.
Borrowed from Spanish {estrella} 'star'.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'. Distinct from bərcˈir-e {bărţíre} 'big stone, rock' [Papahagi 1963: 201; Cunia 2010: 191; Dalametra 1906: 40].
Langreo: pˈyedɾ-a {piedra} 'stone' [González Rato 2016].
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} ˈstoneˈ.

A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} ˈstoneˈ. There are two expressions for ˈstoneˈ in Central Catalan: pˈeðɾ-ə {pedra} and rɔk {roc}. According to [Alòs i Font 2015] there is no difference between them, although there is a tendency to use the second word in the meaning ˈrock / big stoneˈ (under the influence of Spanish {roca} ˈrock / big stoneˈ).
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} ˈstoneˈ.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} ˈstoneˈ.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} ˈstoneˈ.

Some examples are: {ju ja avùt táma de tróki, de ku͡ọlke pítra ke-i me butúa} "I was afraid of the lads who threw a few stones at me" [Bartoli 2002: 225]; {ju kavúa le pítre} "I dig up stones" [Bartoli 2002: 240]. A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
A substrate borrowing. Distinct from pˈyɛr-e {piere} 'stone as material' [Decorte 2015; Pirona 1871: 690, 298-299].
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.

A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'. Distinct from sˈasː-o {sasso} 'rock, stone' [Passerini Tosi 1989: 1017-1018], rˈɔčː-a {roccia} 'rock' [Passerini Tosi 1989: 1000], mˈasː-o {masso} 'boulder, rock, stone' [Passerini Tosi 1989: 676] and from mačˈiɲː-o {macigno} 'rock, boulder, stone' [Passerini Tosi 1989: 651].
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
Grottaminarda: prˈet-ə {préta} 'stone' [Morelli 2015]. A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} ˈstoneˈ.
Designates precious stones as well. Distinct from čˈaʎ-o {chaillo} 'stone, pebble' [EDCT 2014: 170] and per-ˈõn {perron} 'block of stone, stone slab' [EDCT 2014: 836].

15]; {Luogo è in inferno detto Malebolge, // tutto di pietra di color ferrigno} "There is a place in Hell called Malebolge, // wholly of stone and of an iron colour" [Inf. 18]. Distinct from sˈasː-o {sasso} 'rock' ({Più che tu non speri // s'appressa un sasso che da la gran cerchia // si move e varca tutt' i vallon feri} "Nearer than thou hopest // there is a rock, that forth from the great circle // proceeds, and crosses all the cruel valleys" [Inf. 24]), which sometimes, however, can be used in the meaning 'stone' too: {E s'io non fossi impedito dal sasso // che la cervice mia superba doma} "And were I not impeded by the stone, // which this proud neck of mine doth subjugate" [Purg. 11]. The term lˈapid-e {lapide} is not attested.
A common Romance borrowing from Greek {πέτρα} 'stone'.

Polysemy: 'to swim / to float'. Borrowed from some Slavic source.
Borrowed from German {schwimmen} 'to swim'.
-əy- is an imperfective suffix. Borrowed from Macedonian {pliva} 'swim' or Bulgarian {plivam} 'swim'.

1989: 681. Borrowed from Latin {cauda} 'tail'. Although according to [Voinova et al. 1989: 681], the term ʁˈaβ--u {rabo} is used in the meaning 'tail' as well, Pimentel Ferreira mentions {rabo} in the meaning 'bottom' or as cat's/dog's tail in informal contexts. According to him the collocation {a cauda do gato} "cat's tail" is more preferable than {o rabo do gato} [Pimentel Ferreira 2016].
Borrowed from Standard French; has replaced the inherited term kaw {cawe}. Rifondou: kaw {cawe} 'tail'.

Probably borrowed from Franco-Provençal {arbra} 'tree', due to the absence of development of /a/ into /e/ in the stressed closed syllable, see ˈeva {eva} 'water'. The inherited term thus would be ˈɛrb-u {erbo}, which means 'small plant, shrub'. Distinct from pˈyant-a {pianta} 'plant', from lˈeɲ-a {legna} 'wood' and from bɔsk {bòsch} 'forest wood' [Davico 2016].

1985: 299; Gancz 2015. Has no certain etymology, possibly derived from Slavic {kopati} [Ciorănescu 2015]. Distinct from ˈarbor-e {arbore} 'tree', which is used in scientific language, pom {pom} 'fruit tree' [Gancz, 2015] and lemn {lemn} 'wood' [DER 2004: 1045]. Moldavian: kopˈak {copac} 'tree' [Podiko 1973: 170; Borsh & Zaporozhan 1990: 92].
Of substrate origin [Narumov 2001: 184]. Distinct from lˈinː-a {linna} 'wood' [Pintus 2015]. Domus de Maria: mˈatː-a {matta} 'tree'. Distinct from lˈinː-a {linna} 'wood' [Fadda 2015].
Besides this form, Miccichè also mentions mˈakːy-a {makkia} 'tree' [Miccichè 2015]. Of substrate origin. Distinct from lˈiɲː-u {lignu} 'wood' [Leggio 2015].
Borrowed from Latin {calidus} 'warm / hot'. Distinct from kˈɛnt-e {quente} 'hot' [Montoya Bolaños 2015; Franco Grande 1968: 774; Fernández Armesto 1981: 150].
Polysemy: 'warm' / 'hot'. Borrowed from Catalan {calent} 'warm, hot'.
Langreo: blˈaŋk-u {blancu} 'white' [González Rato 2016].

some examples: {come procede innanzi da l'ardore, // per lo papiro suso, un color bruno // che non è nero ancora e 'l bianco more} "E'en as proceedeth on before the flame // Upward along the paper a brown colour, // Which is not black as yet, and the white dies" [Inf. 25]; {L'una era d'oro e l'altra era d'argento; // pria con la bianca e poscia con la gialla} "One was of gold, and the other was of silver; // first with the white, and after with the yellow" [Purg. 9]; {mostrando un'oca bianca più che burro} "display a goose more white than butter is" [Inf. 17]. This term is first time attested in the form {bla(n)cho} in the "Dichiarzaione di Paxia" (1178-1182, Savona) [TdLJdO 2016].  _x0015_The term ˈalb-o {albo} 'white' is not attested in Dante's works. However we find it contrasted with {negro} 'black' in the Veronese Riddle (VIII-IX centuries): {Se pareba boves alba pratalia araba albo versorio teneba et negro semen seminaba}. Michel regards it as a Latinism [Michel 2011: 45], but this is not necessary. It occurs even after Dante, in the XIV-XVth centuries [TdLJdO 2016], but at the time it was no longer the basic term for 'white'.

Probably borrowed from Italian {bora} 'bora = strong, cold, dry wind'. Kovačec translates bˈor-ä as Croatian {bura} ('bora, north-eastern wind'), but some contexts allow us to suppose that this word is used in a broader sense: {Și čia av bora școdit} "But the wind was damaging there, too" (Žejane); {Tota zia bora} "All day the wind (Jesenovik); {Și bora me bate} "And the wind is beating me" (Jesenovik); {Și scapåt-am lu bore} "I escaped the wind" (Jesenovik); {I'll ask the wind} "Ântrebå vo bora" (Jesenovik); {Și borele pușit-a} "And the winds blew" (Jesenovik); {Și cân s-a ploele cu bora} "And when the rains and the wind" (Jesenovik). In Žejane the inherited term vint {vint} 'wind' is preserved [Sârbu & Frăţilă 1998: 298; Byhan 1899: 381], but it is absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.

Borrowed from Slovene {ženska} 'woman' or Croatian {ženska} 'female, woman's' (a feminine form of adjective {ženski}). Distinct from muʎäre {muľę́re} 'wife' [Kovačec 2010; Byhan 1899: 283]. Byhan also mentions the word žˈeɲe {žéńe} 'married woman' [Byhan 1899: 389], Weigand adds the word gospä {gospę} [Weigand, 1899: 397], both forms are absent from Kovačec's dictionary and from texts.
